Mysuru Zoo to conduct a two-day workshop.description: MYSURU: From the start of the New Year, complaints of snakes crawling into roads, and homes have been incrementally rising across the city, and the problem has been particularly more pronounced on the outskirts. As residents have been making frantic calls to snake charmers, and others, adept in taming and rescuing snakes, the Mysuru Zoo, taking cognisance of the gravity of the problem and the lack of adequate training in those called on to attend to snakes, has decided to conduct a two-day workshop to share knowledge on scientific methods of rescuing snakes with the traditional experts. Authorities at the Mysuru Zoo are likely to start the process to identify traditional snake charmers working across the city, and get them to participate in the workshop. The zoo management is equally keen on registering all the snake charmers, who will be issued certificates, which will provide them a degree of authenticity. Besides, these certificates will further help civic agencies and local administration streamline the entire process of rescuing stray snakes, with the certificates helping the authorities maintain a log of charmers, whom both residents and agencies can readily contact. Rise in the number of snakes reported at homes, and roads Mysuru has correspondingly triggered a spike in the number of people identifying themselves as rescuers. However, in the absence of any mechanism to assess their ability, coupled with the lack of government certification has forced residents to take the abilities of the snake rescuers at their word. Presently, zoo authorities estimate that there are as many as 10 rescuers operating in the city. Among the techniques that the rescuers will be taught in the course of the workshop include identification of venomous and non-venomous snakes, safety procedures to be followed during the rescue operation, ethical methods of saving the snake, and moving the reptiles to safer homes. Mysuru Zoo executive director Ajit Kulkarni told STOI that their desire to promote a more scientific approach to rescue of animals was the motivation behind conducting the workshop. “There is an imminent need to streamline the entire process of rescuing, and treating snakes in the city. We are yet to decide on the dates for the workshop,” Kulkarni said. ‘Snake’ Shyyam, a veteran in the field of rescuing snakes, lauded the Mysuru Zoo’s initiative, stating that it would equip amateurs with the right techniques, besides increasing their knowledge about the reptiles. “Many rescuers, while starting out, are unaware about which of the snakes are venomous, and which ones are not. They fray into the profession, prompted by enthusiasm and curiosity. One must become a rescuer, not a catcher. This workshop that the zoo wants to conduct will also learn about instruments that can be used. Most rescuers today use instruments which harm the snakes,” he told STOI. Shyyam called on the zoo authorities to ensure that rescuers, attacked by snakes during rescue operations, received the necessary medical attention. Doctors strike.description: KOLKATA: Junior doctors in Bengal finally called off their week-long strike and promised to resume duty on Tuesday morning, ending a stir that crippled out patient departments (OPDs) and severely hit emergency services at hospitals across the state. At a meeting held at state secretariat Nabanna on Monday evening, West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee told a team of 31 junior doctors, " Lakkhi chhele, ebar tomra strike tule nao (Please withdraw your strike like good boys)", which they agreed to. The "cordial" negotiations between the CM and doctors were broadcast live for about 100 minutes by two regional channels. The doctors, who had adopted a strident posture against the administration for the initial police inaction against the kin of a bereaved patient at NRS Hospital last Monday (incident that triggered the stir) relented in the face of genuine-sounding assurances from the CM. The state administration medical fraternity face-off escalated after Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee issued a stern warning of action against the strike during her visit to SSKM Hospital last Thursday. What could have also played on their minds was the rising public opinion against the continuing strike, especially after the CM's appeal for talks last weekend. The striking doctors returned to the NRS campus on Monday and, after another general-body meeting, made a statement: "We hereby announce the withdrawal of the strike by junior doctors." Several issues were discussed at the meeting. They ranged from security measures - collapsible gates for emergency wards, regulated entry for patients' kin and enhanced police presence on medical campuses with nodal officers responsible for law and order - to the CM's suggestion for third-party PR professionals, who could act as grief counsellors and handle communication between "overworked doctors" and "aggrieved patients' kin" and grievance cells for patients. "We are delighted with the cordial manner in which the meeting was held, the CM's caring touch and concrete suggestions and assurances to the issues raised by us," one of the junior doctors said. "They (doctors) have genuine demands. We have listened to them and taken decisions to resolve them. This must be a continuous process. We have to see to it that such untoward incidents are averted and action is taken if something happens," Mamata said. The CM's "gentleness", however, came with the message that she could not be bullied. Urged by the junior doctors to visit the doctor who was injured in the NRS attack, and come to the NRS campus, she said, "Leave certain things to us...Give me your word that you will resume duty." Patients flood govt hospitals in South K.description: MYSURU: The nationwide strike by doctors remained peaceful in south Karnataka, though it adversely affected the functioning of private hospitals as their OPDs remained shut throughout the day. However, emergency services were available to patients. In the city, 1,200 to 1,300 patients visit K R Hospital every day. However, on Monday, due to the absence of OPD in private hospitals, the number went up to 1,400. Those who came to K R, Cheluvamba and other government hospitals didn’t face much difficulty, but patients visiting private hospital OPDs had a hard time. Though the management of most private hospitals had announced in advance that the OPD would not be functional on Monday, many still thronged their OPDs. The private hospitals had decided to close their OPDs from 6am on Monday to 6am on Tuesday in solidarity with the doctors in West Bengal, who were attacked by the relatives of a patient. Dr Nanjundaswamy, superintendent (incharge), KR Hospital, said: “We had held multiple meetings nearly a week ago. Though our junior doctors were staging protests, we had roped in additional staff and were ready to handle any number of patients. Usually, on an average, 1,200 to 1,300 patients visit KR Hospital while on Monday, due to the shutdown of OPD at private hospitals, the number crossed 1,400.” Dr M S Jayanth, secretary, Indian Medical Association, Mysuru said: “To show solidarity with the doctors of West Bengal, all private hospitals in Mysuru had closed their OPD. The dentists and those working in labs too joined the protest. All labs were also closed. Till Tuesday morning 6am, the OPD will remain closed at all private hospitals. However, the doctors at all private hospitals are attending emergency cases.” In Chamarajanagar, most private hospitals didn't open their OPDs. In the town, doctors took out a protest march, seeking a Central act to protect doctors on duty. As private hospitals didn't open their OPDs, there was a huge rush of patients at Chamarajanagar Institute of Medical Sciences. The hospital authorities said they had made elaborate arrangements to manage the extra rush. In Kodagu also the situation was not different. There was a huge rush at Kodagu Institute of Medical Sciences as the OPDs were not available in private hospitals and the clinics. According to health department sources, the situation was near normal. In Hassan, doctors took out a protest march and medical students demanded stern action against those who attacked the doctors in West Bengal. They urged the Central and state governments to ensure the safety of the doctors working in government hospitals. In Chikkamagaluru and Shivamogga too the doctors held a protest march. The OPD in private hospitals were disrupted by the strike. Patients searching for clinics and doctors were a common scene. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Sumalatha lays onus on youth to protect.description: MANDYA: Actor-turned-politician Sumalatha participated in a public programme — her first after being elected as Mandya MP — at Keelara village of Mandya talk on Tuesday. Speaking at Swaccha Meva Jayate programme, Sumalatha said she was happy that her first-ever event pertains to cleanliness. “We are all duty-bound to protect Mother Earth. We keep talking about having good roads and drainage system, but not on conserving water and ecology. Unfortunately, the people in north Karnataka walk long distances to fetch a pot of water. We will also face such crisis if we don’t take care of ecology and conserve water,” Sumalatha cautioned. Expressing her displeasure over spoiling the serenity and sanctity of tourist and religious places, “and government not doing anything to prevent it”, Sumalatha laid the onus on youth to protect such places. “No one can outpower youth, and it’s time they go out and protect our monuments and rich heritage,” she added. In a lighter vein, Sumalatha told mediapersons not to expect any controversial statements from her. “I don’t give such statements at all,” she said. When asked about chief minister H D Kumaraswamy’s village-stay programme, Sumalatha said it is the chief minister’s idea and he would continue the same. When asked about complaints that she is inaccessible to the people of Mandya and that she does not answer their phone calls, Sumalatha rejected the claims. “One cannot expect me here when I’m away in Delhi,” she said, adding that she will hear the grievances of Mandya people thrice a week. When asked about the absence of district minister C S Puttaraju at the programme, Sumalatha suggested reporters that they ask only him about it. She also evaded questions pertaining to the alleged non-cooperation of elected representatives from JD(S) and DC N Manjushree, whose absence at the programme was conspicuous. Manjushree was taken off poll duty after Sumalatha alleged nepotism against her in the run-up Lok Sabha elections. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Yaduveer Krishnadatta Chamaraja Wadiyar.description: MYSURU: Scion of Mysuru royal family Yaduveer Krishnadatta Chamaraja Wadiyar welcomed the decision of high court to protect and conserve the century-old Devaraja Market and paid a surprise visit to the market on Sunday morning along with his wife Trishikha Kumari. Yaduveer and Trishikha walked into the market which caught the attention of vendors and shoppers. They took a stroll and interacted with the vendors who were tense about the high court’s decision. Yaduveer’s visit to the market served as a signal that Mysureans want to retain the heritage structure where they shop. As they walked in the vegetable and fruit lanes, vendors rose from their seats to pay their due respect to the royal couple. While Trishikha bought fresh vegetables, Yaduveer interacted with the vendors. As they bought commodities from the market, vendors were hesitant to receive money from the royal couple. However, Yaduveer and Trishikha insisted that they take the money. After meeting vendors and assuring them on saving the market from demolition, Yaduveer visited Guru Sweets, which is popular for Mysore Pak. He later bought sweets and interacted with the people who had gathered around his car. By paying frequent visits to the Devaraja Market, Yaduveer has proved time and again that the erstwhile royal family will stand by the vendors and conservation of heritage structures, a vendor said. On Saturday, Yaduveer had issued a statement saying that the high court has upheld the decision to conserve heritage structures. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil. Rangayana recalls lasting association wi.description: MYSURU: Girish Karnad was not a little anxious about Rangayana artistes staging his Kendriya Sahitya Akadami-winning play ‘Taledanda (The Beheading)’, and the ace playwright did not hesitate in expressing his apprehensions with the artistes who approached him seeking permission to perform the text. However, in the aftermath of watching the performance in Rangayana, Karnad was most expansive in his praise of the artistes and the crew, whom he credited with having thoughtfully elevated the protagonist of the play. Karnad had a special bond with Rangayana, the theatre repertory in Mysuru, as he did with its founder, BV Karanth – the doyen of Indian drama. In the 1980s, when Rangayana was still trying to establish itself as a prominent theatre space in the state, Karnad could be spotted here often, and his demise has seen a palpable pall of gloom descend on the repertory. As recently as in December 2018, Karnad with an oxygen container in tow, arrived at Rangayana to inaugurate the winter theatre fest Bahuroopi. The sight of an ailing Karnad, breathing with the help of an electronic apparatus, throwing open the drama fete, was as much an enduring testimony to his love for the stage, as it was for his tryst with Rangayana. In his inaugural address, Karnad reminisced about the many evenings he spent with Karanth at Vanaranga in Rangayana, whiskey keeping the two doyens of theatre company. Karanth had, years before establishing Rangayana in Mysuru, directed one of Karnad’s most celebrated plays ‘Hayavadana’, and the performance of ‘Taledanda’ several years later was a fitting coda to the playwright’s waltz with the repertory. Rangayana artiste Hulugappa Kattimani recalled, with a mixture of grief and nostalgic pride, Karnad’s appreciation for his depiction of the King Bijjala in ‘Taledanda’. “It was this role which set the foundation for my career as a theatre actor. I will remain indebted to Karnad for this,” Kattimani told TOI. The artiste recalled, with visible delight, Karnad’s presence at rehearsals of ‘Taledanda’ that Kattimani was staging with the inmates of Mysuru Central Prison in 2005. “He was impressed with the performances of the prisoners,” he added. The humane doyenFormer Rangayana director Bhagirathi Bai Kadam began her innings in theatre speaking the lines of Girish Karnad on stage. “Along with Karanth, he was the tallest personality in Kannada theatre. I have been very fond of him ever since I forayed into theatre. When I was at the National School of Drama, New Delhi, Karnad would come to see our rehearsals, and remark on our performances, asking us to make corrections where necessary. He was extremely straightforward,” Bhagirathi said. Sharing an anecdote revealing of the humaneness that remained one of Karnad’s calling cards till the very end, Bhagirathi said, “We shared screen space when he adapted Kuvempu’s novel Kanooru Heggathi for television. He played Chandregowda, and I was Subbamma. However, when we had to dub for our roles, I was pregnant with my first child and I was in Assam. In the climax of the serial, my character has to undergo an abortion. But Karnad, taking note of my condition, asked me not to dub for those scenes since they could disturb me.” Karnataka Sahitya Akadami chairman Prof Aravind Malagatti hailed Karnad as a lodestar of Kannada literature. “Karnad, UR Ananthamurthy are no more, but they have left behind legacies rich with their ideologies, which people must imbibe in their daily life,” he said. The tireless activistFormer Ranagayana director H Janardhana, popularly called Jenni, chose to highlight Girish Karnad’s contributions to the welfare of society. He was a fearless activist committed to secularism. “He was staunchly anti-communal,” said Jenni, also highlighting the rich contribution of the playwright to the theatre repertory he once headed. “Karnad is responsible for transforming modern Kannada theatre,” he added. Bahuroopi in playwright’s honourTo honour Girish Karnad’s multifold contributions to literature, Rangayana is planning to host the 2020 edition of its annual winter theatre fest Bahuroopi in his honour. “We will organise a condolence meet on Thursday, where Karnad’s close acquaintances such as Kappanna and H Janardhan, who will speak about him,” said joint director of Rangyana VN Mallikarjunaswamy. - (With inputs from Madiha Khanum) Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Gram panchayat asks public to click phot.description: MYSURU: Appealing to the public to help tackle the mounting problem of construction debris dumped by miscreants near the Bandipalya Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC) at the foot of Chamundi Hills, members of the Hosahundi gram panchayat (GP) have asked residents to take photographs of those unloading waste, and send it to them. The GP members have assured the residents that action will be initiated against those caught causing damage to the environment. However, the problem is not limited to Bandipalya alone. Across the city, construction waste is being indiscriminately unloaded at vacant sites and medians of wide roads – the problem is particularly pronounced on a particularly isolated stretch of the Outer Ring Road (ORR). Repeated complaints from the public to the Mysuru City Corporation (MCC) prompted the civic agency to start work on a plant to demolish construction waste near Kuppaluru village on the city’s outskirts. The project, initiated under the public private partnership (PPP) model is expected to mitigate the problem of managing construction waste in Mysuru. However, with the plant yet to become a reality, mounds of material used and subsequently discarded for construction of buildings such as bricks, stones and concrete continue to find their way to the sides of the road and vacant plots. The aggrieved residents feel that the near ubiquity of mounds of construction debris detracts from the natural beauty of the cityscape, besides destroying the sanctity of sacred places such as the Sri Chamundeshwari temple and Sri Jwalamukhi Tripura Sundari temple near ORR. Hosahundi GP member GB Lokesh told TOI that the subject came up for discussion at a recent meeting of the panchayat. “It was at this meeting that we decided to rope in people to tackle this problem. Besides residents, even those who travel on the stretch can click photographs on their mobile phones and send it to us, or the GP officials. We will initiate legal action against the culprits,” Lokesh said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mysuru City Corporation issues property.description: MYSURU: Among those yet to settle their outstanding dues in property tax owed to the Mysuru City Corporation (MCC) is the Karnataka Police Bhavana on Narasimharaja Boulevard in Mysuru. The MCC, which is owed Rs 1.65 crore in cess by the police department, has issued a seizure notice to the Commandant of the Karnataka Armed Reserve Police (KARP) to hand over control of the building. The bhavana or recreation centre, constructed in 2002 at the behest of then Mysuru city police commissioner collect the completion report – a document issued by the civic agency certifying that the building is ready for occupancy and accommodation — to the MCC, although it started to function from the year when its construction was completed. The amount that the police department in Mysuru has been paying the MCC as property tax on the bhavan is significantly lower than the actual sum that the civic agency is owed in cess. MCC assistant revenue officer Suresh told TOI, “The Karnataka Police Bhavana started operations in 2002. For one thing, the department does not have the completion report, which means that the cess the MCC is owed will include a fine. The recreation centre came under the jurisdiction of MCC Zone 9, but following the delimitation process, it is now in Zone 1. We have been writing to the department for the past one year, seeking payment of our dues. Following the orders we issued demanding Rs 1.65 crore, the officials responded informing us that they could pay only Rs 18 lakh. We have sent notices warning the police department of eviction in 30 days, following which we issued another with a 15-day window. We will also issue notices with a seven- and three–day warning notices. If they continue to default on payment, we will seize the property. The department charges a sum of Rs 2 lakh for each function held there.” MCC’s zone 1 assistant commissioner Ranjit Kumar said that he assumed charge 15 days ago, and on being intimated about the dues owed to the civic agency, instructed the officials to issue a seizure notice to the Karnataka Police Bhavana. “I have told the officials in my zone to prepare a list of all those in our jurisdiction who are yet to pay their dues in property tax. My aim is to give a boost to revenue generation. The MCC commissioner has informed us that we will discuss the subject of pending dues owed to us with the city police commissioner. We will hope for an amicable solution,” Kumar said. Mysuru city police commissioner KT Balakrishna, on being informed about the problem, said that everyone was bound by the law. “We will also abide by all the regulations,” he told TOI. Besides Karnataka Police Bhavana, there are a slew of properties across the city that have piled up dues in cess, said MCC officials. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Docking stations of public bike sharing.description: MYSURU: The Mysuru City Corporation has given permission to tourism department to display its advertisements at the docking stations of Trin Trin public bike sharing system. The decision was taken by MCC council to generate revenue for maintaining the popular project. The decision was taken up during the council meeting held at MCC meeting hall on Friday. At the meeting, MCC officers said that the government, which had promised to provide Rs 20 crore to the project, had sanctioned just Rs 10.7 crore. “Out of it, we have used Rs 7.10 crore. MCC is spending Rs 3 crore for its maintenance in which already Rs 1.54 crore has been spent. MCC is getting a profit of Rs 44.3 lakh through its registration, but is facing loss in maintenance. So it was decided during the meeting with the state government to have advertisements at the docking centre which can generate revenue,” the officer said. Commissioner Shilpa Nag said that Trin Trin is not a revenue-generation project. “But the tourism department has come forward to provide Rs 1.74 crore to display its advertisements in 28 docking stations. The advertisement bylaw is before the government for more than a year. It will not affect the decision to display advertisement in PBS project,” she said. LED street lights When Udayagiri ward corporator Ayub Khan raised the issue regarding replacing the existing streetlights with energy-efficient LED lights, commissioner Shilpa Nag said that already an agency appointed by state government had conducted an energy audit in the city and has recommended to replace 2,480 streetlights with LED lights. “The project is being taken up in PPP model and tenders have been called as per KPTT Act. The remaining streetlights will be replaced in the next phase,” she said. However, corporator Ayub Khan said that there are more than 4,500 streetlights which need to be replaced. “There is hardly three months left for the Dasara celebrations to start and MCC should immediately take up replacing LED bulbs to complete the project before Dasara,” he said. When Kuvempunagar ward corporator Shivakumar asked about the delay in the implementation of online water bill payment facility in the corporation, commissioner Shilpa Nag said that by Monday the online payment will start. “We have also taken up online property tax payment. Four teams including corporators and officers will soon be visiting Tumakuru, Mangaluru, Hubballi – Dharwad and Shivamogga city corporations separately and study the online tax payment. Based on the study, we will chose the best system adopted in any one of the corporation in MCC. The property details will be updated regularly which generate more revenue,” she said. Madikeri: Stalker guns down teacher, end.description: MADIKERI: Adengada Asha, 45, a widowed teacher at a private school in Gonikoppal, was shot dead by Machimada Jagadish, 55, around 8.15am Friday at a bus shelter in Balele, south Kodagu. He then killed himself with the same single-barrel gun. His first shot injured Asha in the head and the second hit her in the chest, killing her instantly. YK Dinesh, a PU student at Vijayalakshmi Junior College, Balele, and PB Pemmi, an estate labourer, rushed to help her but were injured when Jagadish fired indiscriminately.  Asha was a much-loved teacher in Lions High School and villagers and students rushed to pay their last respects. Asha, whose husband died several years ago, had two daughters, one employed and the other a final-year degree student. Jagadish, a coffee grower, lost his wife two years ago and is survived by a daughter. Initially, Jagadish and Asha reportedly shared a friendly relationship but there was some discord over financial matters in recent times. Jagadi sh was said to be blackmailing Asha with a few fake pictures of her. She had complained to Gonikoppal police, who had sent him to prison for a few days. After being released, he threatened to kill her and she complained to the SP. An enraged Jagadish reportedly visited her at home and threatened her. A terrified Asha even installed CCTV cameras around her house. Police said Jagadish was known to tease girls waiting for a bus and would offer to drop them. Urmila Matondkar.description: MUMBAI: The Congress on Friday nominated actress Urmila Matondkar and former Lok Sabha speaker Meira Kumar from Mumbai North and Bihar's Sasaram parliamentary constituencies respectively. The party renominated its sitting MP Ranjet Ranjan from Supaul in Bihar, as it released a list of another 12 candidates for the general elections. With this list, the Congress has so far nominated 305 Lok Sabha candidates. Urmila Matondkar to contest from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency on a Congress ticket.… https://t.co/JweKWNh1FN— ANI (@ANI) 1553836382000It also changed its candidate in Uttar Pradesh's Maharajganj by now fielding Supriya Shrinate in place of Tanushree Tripathi, the daughter of jailed politician Amarmani Tripathi, after facing widespread criticism. "The Congress central election committee has approved the candidature of Urmila Matondkar as party candidate to contest the ensuing general elections from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency in Maharashtra," a party statement said. Matondkar had joined the Congress after meeting Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday and had later said that she was "here to stay". Meira Kumar have been contesting from her Sasaram parliamentary constituency for many years but had lost in the 2014 Lok Sabha polls. Apart from Supriya Shrinate, in the list of 12 candidates released by the party, four are from Bihar and seven from Odisha. The Congress also released a list of 20 candidates for Odisha Assembly election. Renovated central storage reservoirs in.description: MYSURU: Of the 65 administrative wards that Mysuru city has been divided into, water to 20 of these units is supplied from the two central storage reservoirs in Vijayanagar – one of which can hold up to 18 million litres, while the capacity of the other is 27 million litres. Poor maintenance had resulted in the two reservoirs turning into a cavernous cesspool, with dead birds and stray waste items being found in their depths. To make matters worse, wild algae mushroomed inside these tanks, leaving officials exhausted with the sheer effort of having to keep the two basins, which stored water for nearly 35% of the city’s population, clean. Taking note of the seriousness of the problem, the Mysuru City Corporation (MCC) ordered the renovation of the two tanks, and with the project having been completed, the refurbished reservoirs are set to be inaugurated on June 30. Water pumped in Hongalli is filtered, and stored in the two reservoirs. With the two central tanks now cleaned and renovated , residents in the 20 wards will no longer have to bother about the supply of water during odd hours of the day. Renovated with funds to the tune of Rs 27.2 crore allocated under the Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation (Amrut) scheme, the primary objective behind the project was to prevent contamination of water stored in the two reservoirs. Under the project, the two tanks have been strengthened with roof slabs, separate columns, a concrete flooring raft and adequate drainage facilities. In order to prevent mosquitoes from using the tanks as a breeding pool, ventilators covered by a stainless steel mesh have been installed. What is more, galvanised sheets have been erected around the two tanks. Mysuru MP Pratap Simha, accompanied by Chamaraja MLA L Nagendra and Vijayanagar corporator Subbaiah on Wednesday inspected ongoing work at the two reservoirs, and discussed the progress of the project with Karnataka Urban Water Supply Drainage Board executive engineer (EE) Prasanna Murthy and Vani Vilas Water Works EE Harish. Murthy assured the three elected representatives of the work being completed in 15 days. “The two tanks will be ready for inauguration on June 30,” Murthy said. Murthy added that, once the renovated tanks were inaugurated, water would be supplied during peak hours, which would help residents store it in adequate amounts. “We will be able to supply drinking water daily, and we are hoping that the quantity will see a spike,” he said. Among others, water from the two reservoirs is supplied to Krihnaraja Mohalla, Chamaraja Mohalla, Hebbal, Metagalli, Hinkal and Vijayanagar. Residents are likely to feel relieved about the impending inauguration of the renovated tanks. ‘Senior corporators ruling the roost in MCC Council’The Mysuru City Corporation (MCC) Council had become a mafia, fumed Mysuru MP Pratap Simha. “The council is meeting only for formality’s sake. Senior corporators are walking away with a lion’s share of the grants, and obtain approval for all of their projects. I will write to the deputy commissioner, asking him to stay the approval for those projects approved at the recent MCC Council meeting,” said Simha. Asking for accounts on the Rs 68 crore allocated to the civic agency by the central government, Simha said, “These funds must be used judiciously, and primarily to ensure supply of drinking water. But, that is not the case. Senior corporators are running the show at the MCC Council. There is no equitable distribution of funds among all the corporators. These senior corporators have become an oligarchy of sorts. I have brought this problem to the notice of MCC commissioner Shilpa Nag.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Sadhvi Pragya.description: NEW DELHI: BJP MP from Bhopal Sadhvi Pragya Singh Thakur created a controversy on the first day of 17th Lok Sabha on Monday when she suffixed the name of her spiritual guru with hers while taking oath, drawing objections from the opposition. Amid protests and shoutings, Thakur said that it was her full name and she had already mentioned it in the form she had filled for oath taking. The mention of Swami Purna Chetnanand Avdheshanand Giri as suffix to her name evoked sharp reaction from the opposition members who said that such a thing was not permitted. She insisted that the suffix was part of her full name, resulting in an uproar from opposition and slogan shouting in her favour from the ruling benches. Following the din, Pro-tem Speaker Virendra Kumar asked the Lok Sabha secretary general about Pragya's full name. Amid noise and objections, Kumar ruled that only the name written in her election certificate issued by the returning officer would go on record. Thakur, the Malegaon blast accused, took oath in Sanskrit and ended it with 'Bharat Mata Ki Jai' slogan. Thakur defeated Congress stalwart Digvijay Singh to enter the Lok Sabha for the first time. Later, BJP members continued to raise 'Bharat Mata Ki Jai' slogans, teasing the opposition. They started raising slogan after oath taking by every BJP member. After Ganjendra Umarao Singh Patel (BJP) completed his oath with 'Bharat Mata Ki Jai', N K Premchandran (RSP) urged the Pro tem Speaker to maintain the prescribed format of the oath. The Pro tem speaker ruled that the members stick to the format provided. After this, the members of BJP started adding 'Bharat Mata Ki Jai' after end of every oath. Some of the prominent names who took oath from Madhya Pradesh included K P Yadav who defeated Jyotiraditya Scindia, Rakesh Singh, Ramakant Bhargava and Nakul Nath. Indore MP Shankar Lalwani took oath in Sindhi. In Video:Lok Sabha: Sadhvi Pragya made to take oath againDownload The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Govt committed to providing all benefits.description: MYSURU: Affirming the JD(S)-Congress coalition government’s commitment to honour the recommendations of the Raghavendra Auradkar panel, Karnataka home minister MB Patil on Monday said, “The government is committed to providing all the benefits enjoyed by those in the police force to personnel of the prison and fire departments.” The Auradkar report recommends parity in offering benefits to personnel in separate departments, wherein service is the primary objective. Patil, who participated in the 52nd passing-out parade for women jail warders at the Prison Training Institute in the city, said, “The many demands put forward by the staff in prison and fire departments are being deliberated upon by the government. Discussions about implementing the sixth pay commission are under way.” Patil pointed out that the government had, among other initiatives, made provisions for video conferencing, prison call system, installation of 700 LED television sets, et al. “We will allocate around Rs 200 crore for E-Prison. The longstanding demand for setting up of the Karnataka Prison Development Board too will be fulfilled, which will ensure the welfare of personnel working in the prisons,” said the home minister. Patil said that the presence of engineers, and postgraduates among the 170 jail warders who passed out on Monday was a bittersweet reality. “While I am pleased that such highly qualified individuals are joining the prison department, I cannot but help feel disappointed that they are not getting jobs befitting their academic credentials. People must get jobs that are commensurate with their qualifications,” he added. A beaming HS Revanna, inspector general of police (prisons), said that Karnataka was the only state in the country that had successfully filled all the vacancies in the department. “We are full staffed at the moment,” said Revanna, who was pleased with prison department personnel being deputed on election duty – a first in the state. The senior cop added that five central prisons were being constructed in Vijayapura, Bidar, Hassan, Mangaluru and Bengaluru, with Rs 600 crore being earmarked for the purpose. Swetha Bannappa Dalavayi, a native of Gokak, Belagavi district, took home the overall best performer award while Hemavathi GG, a marathon runner with a state level gold medal to her name, was awarded the best outdoor prize. Additional director general of police NS Megharik, principal district and sessions court Suresh K Vontigodi were among those who graced the occasion. Four engineers among newly inducted wardensAlthough the minimum qualification required to become a jail warder is an SSLC certificate, as many as four women with engineering degrees passed out of the Police Training Institute in Mysuru on Monday. Rajamma HK, a native of Nitturu in Malavalli taluk, Mandya district, who passed out of Ghousia College of Engineering, Ramanagara district with distinction, said that she was forced to start hunting for government jobs after receiving a string of disappointing offers from private companies. “I come from a poor family. Both my parents are daily wage labourers. After getting my engineering degree, I attended interviews at more than 10 companies, but all they offered me was a monthly salary of Rs 8,000. I decided to start preparing for competitive examinations, and successfully cleared the recruitment test for the prison department. Now, I am happy because I will be able to supplement the meagre earnings of my parents,” said Rajamma, adding that she hoped to user the knowledge she had acquired in her engineering course to implement reforms in the prison. “I am also keen on writing other competitive examinations and obtain a good position in the future,” she said. Sahana, a native of Kolar district, Manasa from Shivamogga and Roopa from Vijayapura are the three other engineers who were among the 170 women who were inducted as jail warders. Mysuru doctors express solidarity with m.description: MYSURU: Expressing solidarity with their brethren in West Bengal, members of the Indian Medical Association (IMA), Mysuru on Friday expressed their outrage against the attack on a doctor in the eastern state by wearing black badges to work. However, unlike in West Bengal, where a number of doctors refused to attend to work, healthcare professionals in the district decided not to shirk work so as to avoid inconveniencing patients. IMA, Mysuru president Dr SB Prakash said that the whole of the medical fraternity was outraged on learning about the attack on Dr Pariba Mukherjee at the NRS Medical College in Kolkata. Pointing to the resonance that their protest had found across the globe, Dr Prakash said, “The World Medical Association has condemned the attack, and passed a resolution against violence at hospitals and all healthcare centres. The incident reported in Kolkata is barbaric. Dr Pariba Mukherjee’s condition is critical. IMA’s national president Dr Santanu Sen has visited all the medical colleges in Kolkata, and contacted representatives of the West Bengal government, and police officials. Now, four of the culprits involved in the attack have been apprehended. Meanwhile, IMA’s national president-elect Dr Rajan Sharma and general secretary Dr RV Asokan will travel to Kolkata to talk to the resident doctors. We will demand a law to curb violence against doctors.” ‘Doctors from other states will not go to West Bengal’ In the wake of West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee threatening doctors with stringent action in the event of their failure to report back to duty, Dr Prakash said that the entire medical fraternity condemned the manner in which she had handled the incident. Stating that doctors across the country would not cooperate with West Bengal, he added, “Should the West Bengal government request the services of doctors from other states to tide over this crisis, we will not accede to such a plea. Doctors in West Bengal are starting to feel insecure, and the central government must pass a law to safeguard doctors, who are being attacked for no mistake of theirs. We also condemn the statements made by West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee.” He added that hundreds of patients from West Bengal travelled to Bengaluru for treatment. Other members of IMA, Mysuru pointed out that doctors in the eastern state were being targetted for no valid reason, which they said was the reason behind many of them refusing to perform surgeries and diagnose critical cases. “This is one of the reasons why several patients come to Bengaluru from the state,” an IMA, Mysuru doctor said. Vice-president of IMA, Mysuru Dr Sujatha S Rao said that the legislation protecting doctors in Karnataka had ensured that incidents such as the one reported in West Bengal were fewer in number. Mysuru scientist tests formulation to ta.description: MYSURU: The fructification of a city-based scientist’s decade-long research is bound to enrich the fruit of many a farmer’s labour, quite literally – Vasanth Kumar Thimakapura’s plant-based eco-friendly formulation is being touted as the preventive remedy against the much-dreaded Papaya Ring Spot Virus (PRV), a bane for ryots dependent on the horticulture crop for their fortunes. Papaya is a biennial crop, and affliction by PRSV is a commonly reported problem in South Karnataka. Thimakapura averred that the formulation he has come up with is non-toxic, and can help control the spread of virus in other crops such as beans, tomatoes, cucumbers, orchids among others. President of the University of Mysore Old Students’ Association, and director of the technical wing of Green Lifescience Technologies, Thimakapura was determined to come up with a remedy for PRSV, a pestilent menace that is found across the world. For Thimakapura, the greatest reward for his work has been the results that farmers have reported after using his formulation for the past two years. “It has already been tested by farmers across India. This is besides many of the in-house trials that we have conducted,” said the scientist. What sets the formulation – Thimakapura has named it ‘PowerPlus’ – apart is that it helps prevent the onslaught by the virus, and can help cure those plants blighted by it. Unaffected papaya plants in his plot growing beside those affected by PSRV, Thimakapura said, attested to the efficacy of his formulation. “The virus has the potential to trigger an epidemic. As of now, there is no variety of papaya that is resistant to the virus, nor is there a foolproof mechanism that can help protect them from its threat. So, I hope that my product will serve as a boon for farmers,” he said. Consequences of virus infectionStunted growth, and lack of fruit-breaking ability are two of the most disastrous consequences of affliction by the Papaya Ring Spot Virus (PSRV) in papaya plants. Fruits borne by plants infected by the virus often exhibit clear signs of the disease: These include a discernible change in its taste, bumps and characteristic ring-shaped spots on the skin. PSRV spreads through an insect vector at an exponential rate, and all it takes for an entire plot to grow infested is a small clutch of PSRV-blighted plants. “Farmers dread it because it is impossible to contain its spread,” Vasanth Kumar Thimakapura said. MCC commissioner orders survey of teleco.description: MYSURU: The soaring telecom towers, their antennae shooting up into the sky from amid a mass of concrete roofs, have for long been an enduring source of chagrin for residents of Mysuru. Citizens have repeatedly urged the authorities concerned to act against both, the telecom companies and property owners, the latter for allowing the installation of the towers, but to no avail. However, Mysuru City Corporation (MCC) commissioner Shilpa Nag has ordered a survey of towers across the city. The order issued by the civic agency has ignited hope among residents of the towers vanishing from their neighbourhood for good. “Once we have all the necessary information about telecom towers, we will be able to decide on the course of action to be taken,” Shilpa said. The MCC commissioner added that owners of a few telecom companies had procured a stay against statutory action by the civic agency. “But, this order is applicable to very few towers. We are collecting details of towers in all zones, and the status of each one will be duly recorded,” Shilpa added. Meanwhile, the urban development department’s proposal to rid the area falling within a radius of 50m of schools and hospitals of telecom towers continues to hang fire. “The government is yet to issue an order ratifying it. Once the government issues the order, it will become very easy for citizens to voice their concerns. The protracted delay in issuing this order is affecting both local administration, and the public,” said sources in the urban development department. Meanwhile, MCC officials are furious at many telecom companies for the brazenness with which they have flouted rules, installing towers in locations without obtaining requisite permission. “Firstly, they are paying no tax to the MCC. Secondly, these towers are being set up with no approval being sought from government agencies. The entire process of installation of towers, and charging taxes, can be streamlined once the government issues the order,” said an MCC officer. JP Nagar resident Heena Ashok Kumar said that it was saddening to see towers shooting up in nearly all areas of the city. Pointing to the scores of towers rising up near schools, Heena said, “Mobile towers are being installed at homes. There are many problems that residents have to suffer because of these towers, including the incessant noise from the diesel-powered generators. It is frustrating to see the MCC and the Karnataka State Pollution Control Board take no action.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Karnataka: Man gets 10-year RI for rapin.description: MYSURU: A special court has sentenced a man to 10 years of rigorous imprisonment for raping his eight-year-old daughter in Karnataka's Mysuru district. The resident of a village under Periyapatna taluk was found guilty of raping his own daughter on April 14, 2017. The girl’s mother, who is a witness in the case, had lodged a complaint against her husband. Public prosecutor BC Shivarudraswamy told TOI that judge BS Jayashree of the special court, handling cases of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, has also imposed a fine of Rs 30,000 on the convict. Usually, the girl went to watch television programmes at the landlord’s place in Periyapatna where her mother worked. On that day, the girl was late in returning home. The mother went in search of her daughter only to find her missing at the landlord’s place. Later, she along with few villagers launched a search for her only to find her at a tobacco barn with her father who had molested her. The mother was shocked and heartbroken. Without a second thought, the mother rushed to the police station and lodge a police complaint husband. Shivarudraswamy said the court has also ordered a compensation of Rs 4 lakh from Victim Compensation Fund. This is a second conviction in less than five days in the POSCO case in Mysuru. Anantnag Encounter.description: SRINAGAR: An Army Major died while another officer of the same rank and two soldiers were injured in a gunfight at Bidoora village, in Achabal area of south Kashmir's Anantnag district, on Monday, a defence spokesman said. A Pakistani terrorist was killed in the encounter. Major Ketan Sharma of 19 Rashtriya Rifles, who died in the Achabal encounter, belonged to Meerut. A police officer said they had found the body of a Pakistani terrorist and seized arms and ammunition from the encounter site. The identity of the slain terrorist was being ascertained. In another attack, at least nine Army soldiers were injured in an IED blast that targeted a security vehicle of 44 RR at Aarihal village in Pulwama on Monday evening. Those injured in the Achabal gunfight and IED blast were rushed to the Army's 92 Base hospital in Srinagar, officials said. In the third attack in 24 hours, terrorists lobbed a grenade at the headquarters of the 180 CRPF battalion camp in Tral sub-district of Pulwama late on Monday evening. The grenade exploded outside the headquarters. No casualties have been reported. The first attack happened on Monday morning when a team of security men was on a cordon-and-search operation in Achabal. Terrorists fired at the team, who then retaliated. In the Pulwama attack, the terrorists after setting off the IED, opened fire at the Army vehicle. "Initial reports reveal the vehicle suffered extensive damage," the official said. Three of the soldiers injured in the blast were said to be serious, sources said. Soon after the attack, Army, police and SOG reinforcements were rushed to the spot and a massive search operation was launched. A defence spokesman, however, said some of the men sustained minor injuries in the IED blast. Damage was minimal due to the alertness of the patrol party, he said. The vehicle was an armoured ALS and not a Casspir (a mine-resistant, ambush-protected vehicle), he added. In Video:Indian Army’s vehicle attacked by IED in J&K’s PulwamaDownload The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Minor girl held hostage, raped for five.description: MYSURU: The incident of a 15-year-old schoolgirl being held hostage and raped by five different men for over five months in the city has sent shockwaves across the district. The girl was forcefully taken away by a moneylender on January 7 as the girl’s mother failed to repay a loan. Five people, including the moneylender Padhma, have been booked under various sections of IPC and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (Pocso). A police constable, who is friend of Padhma, too, was allegedly involved in the crime. But he has not been named in the FIR. An IPC section (whoever being a police officer commits rape), however, has been included in the FIR and a probe is under way. Police commissioner K T Balakrishna told TOI that two people have been arrested and search is on for other accused. “The incident has left the family in a state of shock with the survivor’s father attempting suicide after learning about the experience his daughter had to undergo at the hands of the moneylender and her friends. The family is feeling threatened,” a child activist claimed. On the other side, the incident has also exposed the practice of lending money at high rates of interest that is going on unabated. Sources claimed that the girl’s mother had taken Rs 3 lakh from Padhma, her friend, to fend for her treatment on weekly interest. As the family failed to pay the money back, Padhma forcefully took away her daughter, a class IX student. The girl was rescued with the help of Odanadi Seva Samsthe on June 6 and an FIR was filed on June 10. The other accused in the case are Prasanna, Vinodh, a lecturer, Ravi and Vicky. Procedures not followed: ForumOdanadi Seva Samsthe director L Parashuram told TOI that the girl’s mother had approached them and subsequently they met senior police officers seeking help. “We were kept away from the rescue operation by Kuvempunagar police who rescued the girl and sent her with parents. A day later the girl’s family again approached us following which we took them to the Child Welfare Committee (CWC), a quasi-judicial body, which took cognizance of the case and handed over the girl’s custody to us,” he said. The same day police took the survivor from Odanadi for a medical test and then to the judge for recording statements. After the procedures were completed, police didn’t bring back the girl to Odanadi. Officials claimed that the girl expressed her wish of going with her parents before the judge and she was again sent with her mother. Parashuram said the jurisdictional police did not follow procedures and threw the laws governing children and rape survivors to wind. “We have explained the development to CWC and are awaiting their directive,” he added. CWC chairperson Kamala H T said, “We have sent the girl to Odanadi, but the childcare and protection institution has written to us about the developments. The case will be taken up for hearing on Friday.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Attack on Dalit youth: Protests erupt in.description: MYSURU: A day after a video of a dalit youth being thrashed and paraded naked in Gundlupet taluk went viral on social media, various organisations held protests demanding arrest and severe punishment to the accused involved in the crime. According to sources, though the incident took place on June 3, it came to light only after a video of the same went viral. On Wednesday, members of Dalit Sangharsha Samithi led by its convener Bettaiah Kote held a protest near the deputy commissioner’s office. Shouting slogans against the accused, the protesters demanded the arrest of all involved in the crime. “If they had a problem with a dalit entering the temple, they should have called police. We condemn the district administration and the police for not initiating action against the accused persons,” he said. The protesters also submitted a memorandum to the deputy commissioner’s office. The Karnataka Dalit Sangarsha Samiti held a protest in front of taluk panchayat office in Gundlupet. The protest was led by district convener K Nanjappa Basavanagudi. “The government should immediately arrest all the accused persons involved in the incident,” he demanded. Another dalit organisation also held a protest infront of Dr BR Ambedkar’s statue opposite Town Hall. They shouted against the state government. “Even after 70 years of Constitution, the dalits have been facing humiliation in the society. We will hold a nationwide protest if the accused persons are not arrested,” they said. Meanwhile, district convenor of DSS, a dalit organisation, Choranahalli Shivanna, alleged the police are soft on the accused persons. “We are holding a bandh next week in protest against the attitude of police,” he said. However, progressive thinker Mahadeva Bharani said a delegation would be meeting chief minister H D Kumaraswamy and deputy CM G Parameshwara and demand that steps be taken to prevent such incidents. They will also demand that the deputy commissioner, SP and police inspector be transferred. Save Constitution Karnataka Abhiyan president Padma too said that they would be holding a state-wide protest against the incident in coming days. Chanchal Lahiri.description: KOLKATA: After a day-long search for magician Chanchal Lahiri (41),   who disappeared   while performing an underwater escape act in the Hooghly, police on Monday fished out his body from near Howrah. Later in the evening, Lahiri's brother identified his body. An initial police probe established that Lahiri on Sunday had made several mistakes while attempting the stunt popularised by the famous illusionist and stunt performer Harry Houdini almost 100 years ago. Mandrake trying similar stunt earlierMMiC still in shock after magician’s deathLahiri, who was to come out of the water after being thrown in with his hands and feet bound, , but also wore cumbersome clothing and guards that made swimming in the strong current extremely difficult. Magician PC Sarkar, a master of such stunts, said perhaps Lahiri "needed a little more practice". Lahiri's team, too, waited about 15 minutes after he was lowered into the water to raise an alarm. Chanchal Lahiri on the boat moments before he started the stunt on Sunday Lahiri’s hands and legs were tied with ropes and he was chained with six locks. "When he did not surface for a long time, people panicked. Some onlookers said they saw a man struggling, seeking help, in the middle of the river. Police were informed and a team of divers from the disaster management group joined the rescue operation," said DC (Port) Syed Waquar Raza. Cops will probe if he took advantage of some lacunae on part of the administration and probably paid for it with his life. "A case of negligence is likely to be registered," said a source. Lahiri being lowered into the Hooghly river as he performed one of his tricks in KolkataMagician’s body found; peers say he didn’t take proper precaution Sources said Mandrake never mentioned in his permission letter that he was going to jump into the water. "Lahiri stated the stunt was to happen on a boat or vessel. Hence, we allowed him permission," Raza said. The letter added that he wanted to take photographs and perform an extra event around 1.30pm. The final dip made by Chanchal Lahiri"He performed almost an hour earlier. Hence, river traffic police was absent," said a Port division officer. Police said Lahiri drowned around 12.30pm and it is unclear whether he was performing or practising the act. Moments before the stunt on Sunday, Lahiri said, "If you perform a dangerous trick perfectly, you are a magician. If you fail, it is always tragic." Mandrake's body was fished out on Monday"Bound and chained, Mandrake was lowered 30 feet under water. Thousands watched and it is impossible the cops missed the entire episode when even politicians were present," claimed a friend on Monday. In 2013, when Lahiri performed the same stunt, he was assaulted by the crowd of onlookers, who claimed they felt cheated because they had seen through the trick. BJP List 2019 WB.description: KOLKATA: The BJP in its first list of 28 candidates for West Bengal has pinned hopes on its veterans and defectors from the ruling Trinamool Congress to take on the Mamata Banerjee's government in the state. Of the 28 candidates, nearly 25 are new faces, with a thrust on active political workers rather than greenhorns from the glamour world. The saffron party, which bagged two Lok Sabha seats in the 2014 elections, is now targeting 23 of the state's 42 constituencies. BJP Lok Sabha first full listUnlike the TMC list, which had 18 new faces and a mix of both old-timers and greenhorns, hardcore politicians and personalities from the film industry, the BJP has put faith on its own leaders and defectors from other parties. There are four women candidates and one Muslim nominee in the first list. Of the candidates, five had recently defected to the saffron party from the Trinamool Congress and one from the CPI(M). West Bengal: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageUnion minister and BJP MP from Asansol Lok Sabha constituency Babul Supriyo has been renominated from the same seat and is pitted against actor Moon Moon Sen of the TMC. State BJP president Dilip Ghosh will contest from Medinipur seat against TMC leader Manas Bhunia. BJP national secretary Rahul Sinha will take on TMC heavyweight Sudip Bandopadhyay in Kolkata North Lok Sabha seat. State BJP vice-president and Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose grandnephew, Chandra Kumar Bose will contest from Kolkata South Lok Sabha seat. Former IPS officer Bharati Ghosh, once known to be close to Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, will be fighting against TMC candidate and actor Dipak Adhikary, popularly known as 'Dev', from Ghatal Lok Sabha constituency. The BJP has fielded former Trinamool Congress MLA Arjun Singh from Barrackpur Lok Sabha seat. Singh, who had recently joined the saffron party, has been pitted against TMCs Dinesh Trivedi. In Coochbebar Lok Sabha seat, the party has fielded former TMC youth leader Nishith Pramanik, while in Jadavpur Lok Sabha seat, expelled TMC MP Anupam Hazra will contest against TMC's Mimi Chakraborty, an actor by profession. Another former TMC MP Soumitra Khan, who joined the BJP in January, has been given ticket from Bishnupur(SC) Lok Sabha seat. Former CPI(M) MLA Khagen Murmu, who too had switched over to the BJP, will contest from Malda North seat and will take on TMCs Mausam Benazir Noor, who had recently defected to the party from the Congress, in Malda Uttar seat. The Lok Sabha elections in the state will be held from April 11 till May 19 in seven phases. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Englisgh medium classes: First-time lear.description: MYSURU: A government school in Yelewala, about 14 km from Mysuru city, has been renamed Karnataka Public School (KPS) after addition of English medium sections. Hemalatha S, the class teacher for new English medium first grade, engages her 18 students in drawing and various activities by using English words and sentences to familiarise them with basic elements of the language. The students hail from poor families and this is their first exposure to the language. None of them attended nursery or pre-nursery where kids gain a very basic understanding of English. But the 18 students are quick learners and have been able to follow simple sentences after a week of classes. They answer questions and identify numbers, common objects and colours. Hemalatha recently underwent a 15-day training for the classes. Until now, she had been teaching English to students in higher grades. She is impressed by her new students and believes they will learn even faster in the coming weeks. “They found things difficult in the first few days, but they picked up quickly later. I speak in English most of the times in the classroom,” she said. RH Siddannaiah, a cluster resource official, observed that many parents applied for their children’s admission at the school even though it was surrounded by private schools. Principal Siddegowda and vice-principal Prabha M expect more students to join from next year. “If transport facilities are provided, children from neighbouring villages may also come here,” Siddegowda said. How they are being taught in school Teacher: What is this? Students: Paper Teacher: Indu, look here. Does the paper roll or slide? Students: Slide Teacher: Give me a water bottle...This bottle... does it roll or slide? Students: Roll Teacher: What is this? Students: Pen Teacher: Does it roll or slide? Students: Roll. Teacher: It rolls. Sometimes it also slides. The pen rolls as well as slides. Very good. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mahagathbandhan.description: NEW DELHI: Taking a swipe at the grand alliance of opposition parties, finance minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the 'mahagathbandhan' is a 'non-bandhan', political circus and a recipe for chaos. Several political parties, mostly traditional BJP opponents, have come together to take on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the ensuing general elections beginning April 11. In a blog post, Jaitley said that over the last several months, India was "exhausted" with the talk of a 'Mahagathbandhan'. The rationale, he said, was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP were very strong and could not be challenged by individual party. Stressing that Indians judge politicians by their merit and capacity and no longer by any traditional loyalty, he said: "We were promised a 'coalition of rivals' because India had to be saved. We were promised a common minimum agenda. Each leader amongst the aspirant Prime Ministers wanted to become a 'sutradhar' (anchor) of the alliance. He/she would periodically organise shows in his/her State and invite the entire bandwagon." In opposition camp, Jaitley said there is a tussle for leadership as already multiple candidates have made their desire clear to take over the mantle of the leadership. According to him, each one of them is interested to see the strength of the other party's contender depleting and also have high hopes in a chaotic and highly hung Parliament. "He/ she believes that only in a chaotic situation he/she has a chance," said Jaitley, who is heading the BJP's publicity division of the seven-phase Lok Sabha elections. The past track record of such governments in terms of policy, longevity and growth has to be borne in mind, he said adding their track record of corruption is equally well-known. Jaitley further said it is only because of the size of the BJP and clarity on leadership in the last coalition that a successful government was run under Prime Minister Modi. "Today you have no 'gathbandhan' let alone 'mahagathbandhan'. It is a 'non-bandhan'. You have no leader, no programme, no meeting of minds. "Stability, which is paramount, is a major casualty. The only thing in common is negative agenda 'remove one man'. It is a recipe for chaos," he said in the blog titled 'A Political Circus Called 'Mahagathbandhan'. The nominations for the first two phases of polling are over and those for the third phase are about to happen. The results will be announced on May 23.
